habitat_description: Perognathus longimembris pacificus is a disjunct subspecies of the P. longimembris species residing in very small population clusters along the southern coast of California between Los Angeles and San Diego. It is a nocturnal, burrow dwelling rodent restricted to arid, loamy and fine sandy habitats of Mediterranean coastal environments within 4-6 km of the coastline (Hall 1981, Williams 1986, Williams et al. 1993, Spencer 2005). Recent surveys have located the subspecies in coastal sage scrub marine terraces with a dominantly sandy soil (USFWS 1998). These habitats often include Artemisia sage scrub, perennial grasses and forbs along with unvegetated, sandy areas (Meserve 1976, Brylski 1993). Spencer and M. Pavelka (Spencer 2005) created habitat suitability models for the Pacific pocket mouse for San Diego and Orange counties using a combination of soils and vegetation data. They ranked as high suitability open coastal scrub and grassland habitats with a diversity of annual herbs and ranked low habitats of dense shrubs, wetlands, or woodlands. They considered areas of agriculture, development, disturbed, rock, or open water as having "no potential" for occupancy. Because of the fossorial nature, soil texture is a more important component of habitat suitability than vegetation. Additionally, Spencer (2005) reports that shurb thinning experiments conducted within home ranges of known Pacific pocket mouse locales had a positive affect on individual movements (i.e. from denser to less dense shrub cover) suggesting preference for a sparser shrub overstory. MJR 2 August 2012.
